name: Abusive Ad Hominem
description: See Ad Hominem.
logicalForm: Person A makes claim X. Person A has negative trait Y. Therefore, claim X is false.
example: You can't trust John's opinion on climate change because he's been divorced twice.

name: Accent
description: The Accent Fallacy is a fallacy of ambiguity due to the different ways a word or syllable is emphasized or accented.
logicalForm: Phrase P has meaning M when emphasized one way. Phrase P has different meaning N when emphasized differently. Therefore, P is ambiguous.
example: A contract states: 'This agreement may be terminated with 30 days notice.' Emphasizing 'may' suggests optional termination, while emphasizing 'terminated' suggests mandatory termination.

name: Accentus
description: See the Fallacy of Accent.
logicalForm: Same as Accent fallacy
example: Same as Accent fallacy

name: Accident
description: We often arrive at a generalization but don't or can't list all the exceptions.
logicalForm: General rule G applies to most cases. Therefore, G applies to this specific case (ignoring exceptions).
example: Cutting people with knives is illegal (surgery exception). Therefore, surgeons should be arrested.

name: Ad Baculum
description: See Scare Tactic and Appeal to Emotions (Fear).
logicalForm: If you don't accept X, then bad consequence Y will happen to you. Therefore, accept X.
example: You should agree with my political views or you might find your car vandalized.

name: Ad Consequentiam
description: See Appeal to Consequence.
logicalForm: I wish X were true/false. Therefore, X is true/false.
example: I don't believe in climate change because addressing it would hurt the economy.

name: Ad Crumenum
description: See Appeal to Money.
logicalForm: Person/Position X is wealthy. Therefore, X is correct/credible.
example: This financial advice must be good because it comes from a billionaire.

name: Ad Hoc Rescue
description: Psychologically, it is understandable that you would try to rescue a cherished belief from trouble.
logicalForm: Evidence E challenges theory T. Instead of rejecting T, add unsupported modification M to preserve T.
example: Astrologer: Your horoscope said you'd meet someone important today! You: I met my mail carrier. Astrologer: That counts! Mail carriers are important!

name: Ad Hominem
description: Your reasoning contains this fallacy if you make an irrelevant attack on the person arguing and suggest that this attack undermines the argument itself.
logicalForm: Person A makes claim X. Person A has negative characteristic Y. Therefore, claim X is false.
example: We should reject Mary's proposal for school reform because she dresses unfashionably.

name: Ad Hominem, Circumstantial
description: See Guilt by Association.
logicalForm: Person A makes claim X. Person A belongs to group G (which I dislike). Therefore, claim X is false.
example: Don't listen to her environmental proposals - she belongs to the Sierra Club!

name: Ad Ignorantiam
description: See Appeal to Ignorance.
logicalForm: X has not been proven false. Therefore, X is true. OR X has not been proven true. Therefore, X is false.
example: No one has proven aliens don't exist, so they must exist.

name: Ad Misericordiam
description: See Appeal to Emotions.
logicalForm: Appealing to pity to support a conclusion
example: Professor, I deserve an A because my dog died during finals week.

name: Ad Novitatem
description: See Bandwagon.
logicalForm: X is new. Therefore, X is better than old alternatives.
example: Our software is the latest version, so it must be superior to competitors' products.

name: Ad Numerum
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: Many people believe X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Millions of people believe in astrology, so it must be valid.

name: Ad Populum
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: Most people believe X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Everyone knows that brand is best, so you should buy it too.

name: Ad Verecundiam
description: See Appeal to Authority.
logicalForm: Person A (inappropriate authority) claims X. Therefore, X is true.
example: A famous actor endorses this medical treatment, so it must be effective.

name: Affirming the Consequent
description: If you have enough evidence to affirm the consequent of a conditional and then suppose that as a result you have sufficient reason for affirming the antecedent...
logicalForm: If P then Q. Q is true. Therefore, P is true.
example: If it's raining, the streets are wet. The streets are wet. Therefore, it's raining. (Ignores other causes like street cleaning)

name: Against the Person
description: See Ad Hominem.
logicalForm: Same as Ad Hominem
example: Same as Ad Hominem

name: All-or-Nothing
description: See Black-or-White Fallacy.
logicalForm: Presenting only two alternatives when more exist
example: Either you support unlimited gun rights or you want to take all guns away.

name: Ambiguity
description: Any fallacy that turns on ambiguity.
logicalForm: Word W has multiple meanings. Meaning M1 is used in premise, meaning M2 is used in conclusion.
example: Criminal actions are illegal. All murder trials are criminal actions. Therefore, all murder trials are illegal. (Equivocation on 'criminal')

name: Amphiboly
description: This is an error due to taking a grammatically ambiguous phrase in two different ways during the reasoning.
logicalForm: Ambiguous grammatical structure leads to incorrect interpretation
example: The police were told to stop drinking after midnight. (Does this mean police shouldn't drink after midnight, or that they should stop people from drinking after midnight?)

name: Anecdotal Evidence
description: This is fallacious generalizing on the basis of a some story that provides an inadequate sample.
logicalForm: Single instance or story S supports general claim C. Therefore, C is true.
example: My grandfather smoked a pack a day and lived to 95, so smoking isn't harmful.

name: Anthropomorphism
description: This is the error of projecting uniquely human qualities onto something that isn't human.
logicalForm: Non-human entity E exhibits behavior B. Humans exhibit B with intention I. Therefore, E has intention I.
example: My cat knocked over the vase because she was angry with me.

name: Appeal to Authority
description: You appeal to authority if you back up your reasoning by saying that it is supported by what some authority says on the subject.
logicalForm: Authority A says X is true. Therefore, X is true.
example: A celebrity claims this diet works, so it must be scientifically valid.

name: Appeal to Consequence
description: Arguing that a belief is false because it implies something you'd rather not believe.
logicalForm: Believing X would have bad consequences. Therefore, X is false.
example: Climate change can't be real because dealing with it would require major economic changes.

name: Appeal to Emotions
description: Your reasoning contains the Fallacy of Appeal to Emotions when someone's appeal to you to accept their claim is accepted merely because the appeal arouses your feelings...
logicalForm: Emotion E is evoked regarding claim X. Therefore, X is true/false.
example: You should hire me because I have a family to support and really need this job.

name: Appeal to Force
description: See Scare Tactic.
logicalForm: Accept X or negative consequence Y will occur.
example: Agree with my position or I'll make sure you're fired.

name: Appeal to Ignorance
description: The Fallacy of Appeal to Ignorance comes in two forms...
logicalForm: X has not been proven false. Therefore, X is true. OR X has not been proven true. Therefore, X is false.
example: No one has ever proven that ghosts don't exist, so they must exist.

name: Appeal to Money
description: The Fallacy of Appeal to Money uses the error of supposing that, if something costs a great deal of money, then it must be better...
logicalForm: X is expensive/wealthy. Therefore, X is good/correct.
example: This luxury car must be better than cheaper models because it costs twice as much.

name: Appeal to Past Practice
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: X has traditionally been done. Therefore, X is correct.
example: We've always used coal power, so we shouldn't switch to renewables.

name: Appeal to Pity
description: See Appeal to Emotions.
logicalForm: Pity is evoked regarding X. Therefore, X should be accepted.
example: You should give me a passing grade because I tried really hard and had a difficult semester.

name: Appeal to Snobbery
description: See Appeal to Emotions.
logicalForm: X is associated with elite/upper class. Therefore, X is superior.
example: Only sophisticated people appreciate this art, so you should say you like it too.

name: Appeal to the Gallery
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: Claim X is popular with this audience. Therefore, X is true.
example: This policy proposal received loud cheers, so it must be sound.

name: Appeal to the Masses
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: The masses believe X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Millions of people use this app, so it must be the best.

name: Appeal to the Mob
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: The mob believes X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Everyone in this angry crowd knows he's guilty, so he must be.

name: Appeal to the People
description: If you suggest too strongly that someone's claim or argument is correct simply because it's what most everyone believes...
logicalForm: Many people believe X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Most people believe in some form of afterlife, so it must exist.

name: Appeal to the Stick
description: See Appeal to Emotions (fear).
logicalForm: Accept X or face negative consequences.
example: You should support this policy or you'll be seen as unpatriotic.

name: Appeal to Unqualified Authority
description: See Appeal to Authority.
logicalForm: Person A (unqualified) claims X. Therefore, X is true.
example: A famous athlete says this investment is good, so it must be.

name: Appeal to Vanity
description: See Appeal to Emotions.
logicalForm: Accepting X makes you seem sophisticated/superior. Therefore, accept X.
example: Smart people like you understand why this policy is necessary.

name: Argument from Ignorance
description: See Appeal to Ignorance.
logicalForm: Same as Appeal to Ignorance
example: Same as Appeal to Ignorance

name: Argument from Outrage
description: See Appeal to Emotions.
logicalForm: Outrage is expressed about X. Therefore, position about X is correct.
example: How dare you question this policy after all the sacrifices we've made!

name: Argument from Popularity
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: Same as Appeal to the People
example: Same as Appeal to the People

name: Argumentum Ad ….
description: See Ad …. without the word 'Argumentum.'
logicalForm: Varies by specific Ad fallacy
example: Varies by specific Ad fallacy

name: Argumentum Consensus Gentium
description: See Appeal to Traditional Wisdom.
logicalForm: All nations/cultures believe X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Every culture has some form of religion, so religious belief must be true.

name: Availability Heuristic
description: We have an unfortunate instinct to base an important decision on an easily recalled, dramatic example...
logicalForm: Vivid example E is recalled. Therefore, E represents the general case.
example: After seeing news reports about plane crashes, you believe air travel is more dangerous than car travel (despite statistics showing otherwise).

name: Avoiding the Issue
description: A reasoner who is supposed to address an issue but instead goes off on a tangent...
logicalForm: Issue I is raised. Instead of addressing I, discuss unrelated issue J.
example: Question: How will you address the budget deficit? Answer: Let's talk about our opponent's scandal instead!

name: Avoiding the Question
description: The Fallacy of Avoiding the Question is a type of Fallacy of Avoiding the Issue that occurs when the issue is how to answer some question.
logicalForm: Question Q is asked. Answer addresses different question R.
example: Reporter: Did you embezzle funds? Politician: I've always served my constituents honorably.

name: Bad Seed
description: Attempting to undermine someone's reasoning by pointing our their 'bad' family history...
logicalForm: Person A makes claim X. Person A comes from 'bad' family. Therefore, claim X is false.
example: His ideas about economics can't be trusted - his father was a criminal.

name: Bald Man
description: See Line-Drawing.
logicalForm: Cannot define exact boundary for vague concept. Therefore, concept is meaningless.
example: One grain of sand isn't a heap. Adding one grain doesn't make a heap. Therefore, no amount of sand makes a heap.

name: Bandwagon
description: If you suggest that someone's claim is correct simply because it's what most everyone is coming to believe...
logicalForm: Many people are starting to believe X. Therefore, X is true.
example: All the smart investors are buying cryptocurrency, so you should too.

name: Begging the Question
description: A form of circular reasoning in which a conclusion is derived from premises that presuppose the conclusion.
logicalForm: X is true because X is true (circular support)
example: The Bible is true because God wrote it, and we know God exists because the Bible says so.

name: Beside the Point
description: Arguing for a conclusion that is not relevant to the current issue.
logicalForm: Argument supports conclusion Y. But the issue requires supporting conclusion Z.
example: Debate about environmental policy: My opponent has never even gone camping!

name: Biased Generalizing
description: Generalizing from a biased sample.
logicalForm: Sample S is biased/unrepresentative. Therefore, generalization from S is unreliable.
example: Survey of luxury car owners shows high life satisfaction, therefore all car owners are highly satisfied.

name: Biased Sample
description: See Unrepresentative Sample.
logicalForm: Same as Unrepresentative Sample
example: Same as Unrepresentative Sample

name: Biased Statistics
description: See Unrepresentative Sample.
logicalForm: Same as Unrepresentative Sample
example: Same as Unrepresentative Sample

name: Bifurcation
description: See Black-or-White.
logicalForm: Same as Black-or-White
example: Same as Black-or-White

name: Black-or-White
description: The Black-or-White fallacy limits you unfairly to only two choices...
logicalForm: Only options A and B exist. A is unacceptable. Therefore, B must be chosen.
example: Either we cut all education funding or we go bankrupt. We can't go bankrupt, so we must cut all education funding.

name: Caricaturization
description: Attacking a person's argument by presenting a caricaturization...
logicalForm: Opponent's position X is misrepresented as extreme position Y. Y is refuted. Therefore, X is refuted.
example: Environmentalists want to shut down all industry and return to the Stone Age!

name: Changing the Question
description: This is another name for the Fallacy of Avoiding the Question.
logicalForm: Same as Avoiding the Question
example: Same as Avoiding the Question

name: Cherry-Picking
description: Cherry-Picking the Evidence is another name for the Fallacy of Suppressed Evidence.
logicalForm: Only evidence supporting position X is presented. Contrary evidence is ignored.
example: Quoting only positive reviews of a product while ignoring negative ones.

name: Circular Reasoning
description: The Fallacy of Circular Reasoning occurs when the reasoner begins with what he or she is trying to end up with.
logicalForm: X is true because Y is true; Y is true because X is true
example: Free markets are efficient because they allocate resources optimally, and we know they allocate optimally because they're efficient.

name: Circumstantial Ad Hominem
description: See Ad Hominem, Circumstantial.
logicalForm: Same as Ad Hominem, Circumstantial
example: Same as Ad Hominem, Circumstantial

name: Clouding the Issue
description: See Smokescreen.
logicalForm: Same as Smokescreen
example: Same as Smokescreen

name: Common Belief
description: See Appeal to the People and Traditional Wisdom.
logicalForm: X is commonly believed. Therefore, X is true.
example: Everyone knows that, so it must be right.

name: Common Cause
description: This fallacy occurs during causal reasoning when a causal connection between two kinds of events is claimed when evidence is available indicating that both are the effect of a common cause.
logicalForm: A and B are correlated. Therefore, A causes B. (Ignoring common cause C)
example: Ice cream sales and shark attacks increase together. Therefore, ice cream causes shark attacks. (Ignoring summer heat as common cause)

name: Common Practice
description: See Appeal to the People and Traditional Wisdom.
logicalForm: X is commonly practiced. Therefore, X is acceptable.
example: Everyone speeds on this highway, so it's fine if I do too.

name: Complex Question
description: You use this fallacy when you frame a question so that some controversial presupposition is made by the wording of the question.
logicalForm: Question contains assumption A. Answering directly accepts A.
example: Have you stopped cheating on exams? (Presumes you were cheating)

name: Composition
description: The Composition Fallacy occurs when someone mistakenly assumes that a characteristic of some or all the individuals in a group is also a characteristic of the group itself...
logicalForm: Each part of X has property P. Therefore, X as a whole has property P.
example: Each brick is lightweight. Therefore, the entire brick wall is lightweight.

name: Confirmation Bias
description: The tendency to look for evidence in favor of one's controversial hypothesis and not to look for disconfirming evidence...
logicalForm: Only evidence supporting hypothesis H is considered. Evidence against H is ignored.
example: Only remembering instances when a horoscope was accurate while forgetting inaccurate predictions.

name: Conjunction
description: Mistakenly supposing that event E is less likely than the conjunction of events E and F.
logicalForm: Assuming P(A) > P(A ∧ B) when P(A ∧ B) ≤ P(A)
example: Linda is more likely to be a feminist bank teller than just a bank teller (violating probability rules).

name: Confusing an Explanation with an Excuse
description: Treating someone's explanation of a fact as if it were a justification of the fact.
logicalForm: Explanation E is offered for action A. Therefore, E justifies A.
example: Explaining a crime as resulting from poverty is taken as excusing the crime.

name: Consensus Gentium
description: Fallacy of Argumentum Consensus Gentium (argument from the consensus of the nations).
logicalForm: Same as Appeal to Traditional Wisdom
example: Same as Appeal to Traditional Wisdom

name: Consequence
description: See Appeal to Consequence.
logicalForm: Same as Appeal to Consequence
example: Same as Appeal to Consequence

name: Contextomy
description: See Quoting out of Context.
logicalForm: Same as Quoting out of Context
example: Same as Quoting out of Context

name: Converse Accident
description: If we reason by paying too much attention to exceptions to the rule, and generalize on the exceptions...
logicalForm: Atypical case C is used to challenge generalization G. Therefore, G is false.
example: My turtle lived longer than my tarantula, therefore turtles live longer than tarantulas (ignoring typical lifespans).

name: Cover-up
description: See Suppressed Evidence.
logicalForm: Same as Suppressed Evidence
example: Same as Suppressed Evidence

name: Cum Hoc, Ergo Propter Hoc
description: Latin for 'with this, therefore because of this.'
logicalForm: A and B occur together. Therefore, A causes B.
example: Violent crime increased when ice cream sales increased. Therefore, ice cream causes violence.

name: Curve Fitting
description: Curve fitting is the process of constructing a curve that has the best fit to a series of data points.
logicalForm: Creating an overly complex model that fits existing data perfectly but has poor predictive power.
example: Stock market model that perfectly explains past fluctuations but fails to predict future trends.

name: Definist
description: The Definist Fallacy occurs when someone unfairly defines a term so that a controversial position is made easier to defend.
logicalForm: Term T is defined in biased way B to support argument A.
example: Defining 'fairness' as 'equal outcomes' to support wealth redistribution policies.

name: Denying the Antecedent
description: You are using this fallacy if you deny the antecedent of a conditional and then suppose that doing so is a sufficient reason for denying the consequent.
logicalForm: If P then Q. Not P. Therefore, not Q.
example: If it's raining, the street is wet. It's not raining. Therefore, the street isn't wet. (Ignores other causes)

name: Disregarding Known Science
description: This fallacy is committed when a person makes a claim that knowingly or unknowingly disregards well known science...
logicalForm: Claim C contradicts established science S. Therefore, C is unreliable.
example: Claiming vaccines cause autism despite extensive scientific evidence to the contrary.

name: Digression
description: See Avoiding the Issue.
logicalForm: Same as Avoiding the Issue
example: Same as Avoiding the Issue

name: Distraction
description: See Smokescreen.
logicalForm: Same as Smokescreen
example: Same as Smokescreen

name: Division
description: Merely because a group as a whole has a characteristic, it often doesn't follow that individuals in the group have that characteristic.
logicalForm: Whole X has property P. Therefore, parts of X have property P.
example: The team is excellent. Therefore, every player is excellent.

name: Domino
description: See Slippery Slope.
logicalForm: Same as Slippery Slope
example: Same as Slippery Slope

name: Double Standard
description: There are many situations in which you should judge two things or people by the same standard.
logicalForm: Applying different standards to similar cases without justification
example: Criticizing an opponent for behavior you excuse in your allies.

name: Either/Or
description: See Black-or-White.
logicalForm: Same as Black-or-White
example: Same as Black-or-White

name: Equivocation
description: Equivocation is the illegitimate switching of the meaning of a term that occurs twice during the reasoning...
logicalForm: Word W means M1 in premise, M2 in conclusion (M1 ≠ M2)
example: Only man is rational. No woman is a man. Therefore, no woman is rational. (Equivocation on 'man')

name: Etymological
description: The Etymological Fallacy occurs whenever someone falsely assumes that the meaning of a word can be discovered from its etymology or origins.
logicalForm: Word W originated from meaning E. Therefore, W means E today.
example: 'Terrible' comes from 'terror', so it must always imply something frightening.

name: Every and All
description: The Fallacy of Every and All turns on errors due to the order or scope of the quantifiers 'every' and 'all' and 'any.'
logicalForm: Confusing 'For every x, there is y' with 'There is y such that for every x'
example: Everyone has a mother → Therefore, there is one mother of everyone.

name: Exaggeration
description: When we overstate or overemphasize a point that is a crucial step in a piece of reasoning...
logicalForm: Overstating the strength or scope of claim C
example: This policy will completely destroy our economy! (When it might only have minor impacts)

name: Excluded Middle
description: See False Dilemma or Black-or-White.
logicalForm: Same as Black-or-White
example: Same as Black-or-White

name: False Analogy
description: The problem is that the items in the analogy are too dissimilar.
logicalForm: A is like B in some ways. B has property P. Therefore, A has property P. (But relevant differences exist)
example: Employees are like nails - you have to hit them on the head to get them to work!

name: False Balance
description: A specific form of the False Equivalence Fallacy...
logicalForm: Presenting unequal positions as having equal weight
example: Giving equal airtime to climate scientists and climate change deniers as if their evidence is comparable.

name: False Cause
description: Improperly concluding that one thing is a cause of another.
logicalForm: A and B are associated. Therefore, A causes B.
example: I wore my lucky socks and won the game. Therefore, the socks caused my victory.

name: False Dichotomy
description: See False Dilemma or Black-or-White.
logicalForm: Same as Black-or-White
example: Same as Black-or-White

name: False Dilemma
description: A reasoner who unfairly presents too few choices and then implies that a choice must be made among this short menu of choices...
logicalForm: Presenting only options A and B when C, D, etc. exist
example: Either we ban all guns or we accept school shootings. There's no middle ground.

name: False Equivalence
description: The Fallacy of False Equivalence is committed when someone implies falsely that the two sides on some issue have basically equivalent evidence...
logicalForm: Treating unequal positions/evidence as equivalent
example: Presenting climate science and climate denial as equally valid scientific positions.

name: Far-Fetched Hypothesis
description: This is the fallacy of offering a bizarre (far-fetched) hypothesis as the correct explanation without first ruling out more mundane explanations.
logicalForm: Bizarre hypothesis H explains evidence E. Therefore, H is likely true (ignoring simpler explanations).
example: Claiming missing socks disappear through wormholes instead of considering they get lost in laundry.

name: Faulty Comparison
description: If you try to make a point about something by comparison, and if you do so by comparing it with the wrong thing...
logicalForm: Comparing X and Y that differ in relevant aspects
example: Choosing a car based only on color while ignoring safety ratings.

name: Faulty Generalization
description: A fallacy produced by some error in the process of generalizing.
logicalForm: Drawing broad conclusion C from insufficient or biased evidence
example: Meeting two unfriendly French people and concluding all French are unfriendly.

name: Faulty Motives
description: An irrelevant appeal to the motives of the arguer...
logicalForm: Person A has motive M for claiming X. Therefore, X is false.
example: He only supports that policy because it benefits his business.

name: Formal Fallacy
description: Formal fallacies are all the cases or kinds of reasoning that fail to be deductively valid.
logicalForm: Invalid deductive argument form
example: All A are B. Some C are A. Therefore, some C are B. (Valid) vs. Some A are B. Some C are A. Therefore, some C are B. (Invalid)

name: Four Terms
description: The Fallacy of Four Terms (quaternio terminorum) occurs when four rather than three categorical terms are used in a standard-form syllogism.
logicalForm: Syllogism with four terms instead of three
example: All banks store money. River banks are banks. Therefore, river banks store money. (Equivocation on 'banks')

name: Gambler's
description: This fallacy occurs when the gambler falsely assumes that the history of outcomes will affect future outcomes.
logicalForm: Independent event E has outcome O multiple times. Therefore, opposite outcome is 'due'.
example: The roulette wheel has landed on red five times, so black must be next.

name: Genetic
description: A critic uses the Genetic Fallacy if the critic attempts to discredit or support a claim or an argument because of its origin...
logicalForm: Idea X has origin O. Therefore, X is true/false.
example: That theory came from a communist, so it must be wrong.

name: Group Think
description: A reasoner uses the Group Think Fallacy if he or she substitutes pride of membership in the group for reasons to support the group's policy.
logicalForm: Our group believes X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Real Americans support this policy, so it must be right.

name: Guilt by Association
description: Guilt by Association is a version of the Ad Hominem Fallacy in which a person is said to be guilty of error because of the group he or she associates with.
logicalForm: Person A associates with group G. Group G has bad quality Q. Therefore, A has Q.
example: Her ideas about economics are Marxist because she attended a university with Marxist professors.

name: Hasty Conclusion
description: See Jumping to Conclusions.
logicalForm: Same as Jumping to Conclusions
example: Same as Jumping to Conclusions

name: Hasty Generalization
description: A Hasty Generalization is a Fallacy of Jumping to Conclusions in which the conclusion is a generalization.
logicalForm: Small sample S has property P. Therefore, all things like S have P.
example: Three people from that city were rude, so everyone from that city is rude.

name: Heap
description: See Line-Drawing.
logicalForm: Same as Line-Drawing
example: Same as Line-Drawing

name: Hedging
description: You are hedging if you refine your claim simply to avoid counterevidence...
logicalForm: Original claim C is challenged. Modify C to C' to avoid counterevidence, but present C' as equivalent to C.
example: Psychic: You will meet someone important! (After failure) Well, you met the mail carrier!

name: Hooded Man
description: This is an error in reasoning due to confusing the knowing of a thing with the knowing of it under all its various names or descriptions.
logicalForm: Confusing knowledge by description with knowledge by acquaintance
example: You know who the hooded man is. The hooded man is your father. Therefore, you know who your father is.

name: Hyperbolic Discounting
description: The Fallacy of Hyperbolic Discounting occurs when someone too heavily weighs the importance of a present reward over a significantly greater reward in the near future...
logicalForm: Valuing immediate reward over larger future reward disproportionately
example: Choosing $50 now over $100 a year from now, but choosing $100 in 5 years over $50 in 4 years.

name: Hypostatization
description: Mistakenly supposing that something is a concrete object with independent existence, when it's not.
logicalForm: Treating abstract concept A as concrete entity
example: History demands justice! (Treating history as agent)

name: Ideology-Driven Argumentation
description: This occurs when an arguer presupposes some aspect of their own ideology that they are unable to defend.
logicalForm: Presupposing ideological principle I without justification
example: This policy must be wrong because it conflicts with free market principles. (Without defending why free market principles are absolute)

name: Ignoratio Elenchi
description: See Irrelevant Conclusion. Also called missing the point.
logicalForm: Same as Irrelevant Conclusion
example: Same as Irrelevant Conclusion

name: Ignoring a Common Cause
description: See Common Cause.
logicalForm: Same as Common Cause
example: Same as Common Cause

name: Ignoring Inconvenient Data
description: See Suppressed Evidence.
logicalForm: Same as Suppressed Evidence
example: Same as Suppressed Evidence

name: Incomplete Evidence
description: See Suppressed Evidence.
logicalForm: Same as Suppressed Evidence
example: Same as Suppressed Evidence

name: Improper Analogy
description: Another name for the Fallacy of False Analogy.
logicalForm: Same as False Analogy
example: Same as False Analogy

name: Inconsistency
description: The fallacy occurs when we accept an inconsistent set of claims...
logicalForm: Holding beliefs that cannot all be true simultaneously
example: Believing in absolute free speech but also supporting laws against hate speech.

name: Inductive Conversion
description: Improperly reasoning from a claim of the form 'All As are Bs' to 'All Bs are As'...
logicalForm: All A are B → Therefore, all B are A
example: All cats are mammals → Therefore, all mammals are cats.

name: Insufficient Statistics
description: Drawing a statistical conclusion from a set of data that is clearly too small.
logicalForm: Generalizing from sample size too small to be representative
example: 80% of my three children dislike broccoli, therefore 80% of all children dislike broccoli.

name: Intensional
description: The mistake of treating different descriptions or names of the same object as equivalent even in those contexts in which the differences between them matter.
logicalForm: Confusing co-referential terms in intensional contexts
example: Lois Lane believes Superman can fly. Superman is Clark Kent. Therefore, Lois Lane believes Clark Kent can fly. (False, she doesn't know they're the same)

name: Invalid Reasoning
description: An invalid inference.
logicalForm: Argument with invalid deductive form
example: If it rains, the ground is wet. The ground is wet. Therefore, it rained. (Affirming the consequent)

name: Irrelevant Conclusion
description: The conclusion that is drawn is irrelevant to the premises; it misses the point.
logicalForm: Argument supports conclusion Y, but conclusion Z is needed
example: Debating economic policy: My opponent has never run a business!

name: Irrelevant Reason
description: This fallacy is a kind of Non Sequitur in which the premises are wholly irrelevant to drawing the conclusion.
logicalForm: Premises P are irrelevant to conclusion C
example: We should build a new library because the current one is blue.

name: Is-Ought
description: The Is-Ought Fallacy occurs when a conclusion expressing what ought to be so is inferred from premises expressing only what is so...
logicalForm: Descriptive premises about what is → Prescriptive conclusion about what ought to be
example: People naturally compete for resources → Therefore, we ought not to help the poor.

name: Jumping to Conclusions
description: It is not always a mistake to make a quick decision, but when we draw a conclusion without taking the trouble to acquire enough of the relevant evidence...
logicalForm: Drawing conclusion C without sufficient evidence
example: Seeing wet streets and concluding it rained (ignoring possible street cleaning).

name: Lack of Proportion
description: The Fallacy of Lack of Proportion occurs either by exaggerating or downplaying or simply not noticing a point that is a crucial step in a piece of reasoning.
logicalForm: Over/underemphasizing aspect A of situation S
example: Focusing on a politician's minor gaffe while ignoring their substantive policy positions.

name: Line-Drawing
description: If we improperly reject a vague claim because it is not as precise as we'd like...
logicalForm: Vague concept V has unclear boundaries. Therefore, V is invalid.
example: No single grain makes a heap, so heaps don't exist.

name: Loaded Language
description: Loaded language is emotive terminology that expresses value judgments.
logicalForm: Using emotionally charged terms to influence perception
example: Describing tax cuts as 'relief' and tax increases as 'burdens'.

name: Loaded Question
description: Asking a question in a way that unfairly presumes the answer.
logicalForm: Question with built-in assumption A
example: When did you stop cheating on tests? (Assumes you did cheat)

name: Logic Chopping
description: Obscuring the issue by using overly-technical logic tools...
logicalForm: Focusing on trivial logical details to avoid substantive issues
example: Quibbling over minor definitional issues to derail debate on policy.

name: Logical
description: See Formal.
logicalForm: Same as Formal Fallacy
example: Same as Formal Fallacy

name: Lying
description: A fallacy of reasoning that depends on intentionally saying something that is known to be false.
logicalForm: Asserting false statement as true
example: Claiming a politician said something they never actually said.

name: Maldistributed Middle
description: See Undistributed Middle.
logicalForm: Same as Undistributed Middle
example: Same as Undistributed Middle

name: Many Questions
description: See Complex Question.
logicalForm: Same as Complex Question
example: Same as Complex Question

name: Misconditionalization
description: See Modal Fallacy.
logicalForm: Same as Modal Fallacy
example: Same as Modal Fallacy

name: Misleading Accent
description: See the Fallacy of Accent.
logicalForm: Same as Accent
example: Same as Accent

name: Misleading Vividness
description: When the Fallacy of Jumping to Conclusions is due to a special emphasis on an anecdote or other piece of evidence...
logicalForm: Vivid anecdote A given disproportionate weight over statistical evidence
example: Rejecting vaccination because of one horror story while ignoring large-scale safety data.

name: Misplaced Concreteness
description: Mistakenly supposing that something is a concrete object with independent existence, when it's not.
logicalForm: Treating abstract concept as concrete entity
example: Society decided... (as if society is a thinking entity)

name: Misplaced Burden of Proof
description: Committing the error of trying to get someone else to prove you are wrong, when it is your responsibility to prove you are correct.
logicalForm: Asserting X without proof, then demanding others disprove X
example: I believe in invisible unicorns - prove they don't exist!

name: Misrepresentation
description: If the misrepresentation occurs on purpose, then it is an example of lying.
logicalForm: Distorting opponent's position
example: Opponent: We need moderate gun control. You: My opponent wants to take all your guns!

name: Missing the Point
description: See Irrelevant Conclusion.
logicalForm: Same as Irrelevant Conclusion
example: Same as Irrelevant Conclusion

name: Mob Appeal
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: Same as Appeal to the People
example: Same as Appeal to the People

name: Modal
description: This is the error of treating modal conditionals as if the modality applies only to the then-part of the conditional when it more properly applies to the entire conditional.
logicalForm: Confusing scope of modal operators
example: If you're the king, you must be the king's son. Therefore, everyone must be the king's son.

name: Monte Carlo
description: See Gambler's Fallacy.
logicalForm: Same as Gambler's Fallacy
example: Same as Gambler's Fallacy

name: Name Calling
description: See Ad Hominem.
logicalForm: Same as Ad Hominem
example: Same as Ad Hominem

name: Naturalistic
description: On a broad interpretation of this fallacy, it applies to any attempt to argue from an 'is' to an 'ought'...
logicalForm: What is natural → What ought to be
example: War is natural, so it's morally acceptable.

name: Neglecting a Common Cause
description: See Common Cause.
logicalForm: Same as Common Cause
example: Same as Common Cause

name: No Middle Ground
description: See False Dilemma.
logicalForm: Same as False Dilemma
example: Same as False Dilemma

name: No True Scotsman
description: This error is a kind of Ad Hoc Rescue of one's generalization in which the reasoner re-characterizes the situation solely in order to escape refutation of the generalization.
logicalForm: All A are B. Counterexample C is presented. Therefore, C is not a true A.
example: No Scotsman puts sugar in his porridge. But my uncle Angus is Scottish and does! Well, no true Scotsman puts sugar in his porridge!

name: Non Causa Pro Causa
description: This label is Latin for mistaking the 'non-cause for the cause.'
logicalForm: Same as False Cause
example: Same as False Cause

name: Non Sequitur
description: When a conclusion is supported only by extremely weak reasons or by irrelevant reasons...
logicalForm: Conclusion does not follow from premises
example: He's a great musician, so he'd make an excellent politician.

name: Obscurum per Obscurius
description: Explaining something obscure or mysterious by something that is even more obscure or more mysterious.
logicalForm: Explaining unclear concept U with even more unclear concept V
example: Consciousness arises from quantum entanglement in microtubules.

name: One-Sidedness
description: See the related fallacies of Confirmation Bias, Slanting and Suppressed Evidence.
logicalForm: Presenting only evidence supporting one side
example: Only presenting benefits of a policy while ignoring costs.

name: Opposition
description: Being opposed to someone's reasoning because of who they are...
logicalForm: Person A makes claim X. I oppose A. Therefore, X is false.
example: Rejecting an idea because it comes from a political opponent.

name: Over-Fitting
description: See Curve Fitting.
logicalForm: Same as Curve Fitting
example: Same as Curve Fitting

name: Overgeneralization
description: See Sweeping Generalization.
logicalForm: Same as Sweeping Generalization
example: Same as Sweeping Generalization

name: Oversimplification
description: You oversimplify when you cover up relevant complexities or make a complicated problem appear to be too much simpler than it really is.
logicalForm: Reducing complex situation to simple cause/effect
example: Poverty is caused by laziness.

name: Past Practice
description: See Traditional Wisdom.
logicalForm: Same as Traditional Wisdom
example: Same as Traditional Wisdom

name: Pathetic
description: The Pathetic Fallacy is a mistaken belief due to attributing peculiarly human qualities to inanimate objects...
logicalForm: Attributing human emotions to nature/inanimate objects
example: The cruel sea took their lives.

name: Peer Pressure
description: See Appeal to the People.
logicalForm: Same as Appeal to the People
example: Same as Appeal to the People

name: Persuasive Definition
description: Some people try to win their arguments by getting you to accept their faulty definition.
logicalForm: Redefining term T to include/exclude attributes that favor one's position
example: Defining 'assault weapon' to include all semi-automatic firearms.

name: Perfectionist
description: If you remark that a proposal or claim should be rejected solely because it doesn't solve the problem perfectly...
logicalForm: Solution S is not perfect. Therefore, S should be rejected.
example: This recycling program won't eliminate all waste, so we shouldn't implement it.

name: Petitio Principii
description: See Begging the Question.
logicalForm: Same as Begging the Question
example: Same as Begging the Question

name: Poisoning the Well
description: Poisoning the well is a preemptive attack on a person in order to discredit their testimony or argument in advance of their giving it.
logicalForm: Discrediting person A before they speak, so their arguments are dismissed
example: Before the debate: Remember, my opponent has been paid by special interests.

name: Post Hoc
description: Suppose we notice that an event of kind A is followed in time by an event of kind B, and then hastily leap to the conclusion that A caused B.
logicalForm: A occurred then B occurred. Therefore, A caused B.
example: I wore my lucky hat and my team won. Therefore, my hat caused the victory.

name: Prejudicial Language
description: See Loaded Language.
logicalForm: Same as Loaded Language
example: Same as Loaded Language

name: Proof Surrogate
description: Substituting a distracting comment for a real proof.
logicalForm: Implying proof exists without providing it
example: Experts agree... (without naming them)

name: Prosecutor's Fallacy
description: This is the mistake of over-emphasizing the strength of a piece of evidence while paying insufficient attention to the context.
logicalForm: Miscalculating conditional probability P(A|B) as P(B|A)
example: The probability of this DNA match by chance is 1 in a million, so there's only a 1 in a million chance the defendant is innocent.

name: Prosody
description: See the Fallacy of Accent.
logicalForm: Same as Accent
example: Same as Accent

name: Quantifier Shift
description: Confusing the phrase 'For all x there is some y' with 'There is some (one) y such that for all x.'
logicalForm: Confusing ∀x∃y with ∃y∀x
example: Everyone loves someone → Therefore, there is someone whom everyone loves.

name: Questionable Begging
description: See Begging the Question
logicalForm: Same as Begging the Question
example: Same as Begging the Question

name: Questionable Analogy
description: See False Analogy.
logicalForm: Same as False Analogy
example: Same as False Analogy

name: Questionable Cause
description: See False Cause.
logicalForm: Same as False Cause
example: Same as False Cause

name: Questionable Premise
description: If you have sufficient background information to know that a premise is questionable or unlikely to be acceptable...
logicalForm: Argument based on dubious premise P
example: Assuming without evidence that immigrants commit more crimes.

name: Quibbling
description: We quibble when we complain about a minor point and falsely believe that this complaint somehow undermines the main point.
logicalForm: Focusing on trivial inaccuracies to discredit argument
example: Rejecting climate science because of a minor error in a chart.

name: Quoting out of Context
description: If you quote someone, but select the quotation so that essential context is not available...
logicalForm: Using quote Q without necessary context C, changing meaning
example: Taking 'I oppose this policy' out of context of 'I oppose this policy because it doesn't go far enough'

name: Rationalization
description: We rationalize when we inauthentically offer reasons to support our claim.
logicalForm: Providing socially acceptable reason R for action A, when real reason is different
example: I bought the expensive car for its safety features (when really it was for status).

name: Red Herring
description: A red herring is a smelly fish that would distract even a bloodhound.
logicalForm: Introducing irrelevant topic T to distract from original issue O
example: Debating climate policy: But what about China's emissions?

name: Refutation by Caricature
description: See the Fallacy of Caricaturization.
logicalForm: Same as Caricaturization
example: Same as Caricaturization

name: Regression
description: This fallacy occurs when regression to the mean is mistaken for a sign of a causal connection.
logicalForm: Extreme outcome E1 followed by less extreme E2 → Therefore, intervention caused E2
example: After terrible season, team fires coach. Next season improves slightly → Therefore, firing coach caused improvement (ignoring regression to mean).

name: Reification
description: Considering a word to be referring to an object, when the meaning of the word can be accounted for more mundanely...
logicalForm: Treating abstract concept as concrete entity
example: The market decided... (as if market is conscious entity)

name: Reversing Causation
description: Drawing an improper conclusion about causation due to a causal assumption that reverses cause and effect.
logicalForm: Confusing cause and effect
example: Anxiety causes poor sleep → Poor sleep causes anxiety (possible, but not necessarily)

name: Scapegoating
description: If you unfairly blame an unpopular person or group of people for a problem...
logicalForm: Blaming group G for problem P without sufficient evidence
example: Immigrants are responsible for all economic problems.

name: Scare Tactic
description: If you suppose that terrorizing your opponent is giving him a reason for believing that you are correct...
logicalForm: Accept X or face negative consequence Y
example: Support this policy or you'll be seen as unpatriotic.

name: Scope
description: The Scope Fallacy is caused by improperly changing or misrepresenting the scope of a phrase.
logicalForm: Misinterpreting scope of quantifiers or modifiers
example: Every boy loves some girl → Therefore, there is some girl loved by every boy.

name: Secundum Quid
description: See Accident and Converse Accident, two versions of the fallacy.
logicalForm: Varies by specific fallacy
example: Varies by specific fallacy

name: Selective Attention
description: Improperly focusing attention on certain things and ignoring others.
logicalForm: Noticing evidence supporting belief B, ignoring contrary evidence
example: Remembering only times prayer seemed answered, forgetting unanswered prayers.

name: Self-Fulfilling Prophecy
description: The fallacy occurs when the act of prophesying will itself produce the effect that is prophesied...
logicalForm: Belief B leads to actions that make B true
example: Predicting bank failure causes panic withdrawals that cause failure.

name: Self-Selection
description: A Biased Generalization in which the bias is due to self-selection for membership in the sample...
logicalForm: Sample S self-selected → Generalization from S may be biased
example: Online poll about internet usage only reaches internet users.

name: Sharpshooter's
description: The Sharpshooter's Fallacy gets its name from someone shooting a rifle at the side of the barn and then going over and drawing a target...
logicalForm: Finding patterns in random data after the fact
example: Finding 'predictive' stock patterns after seeing price movements.

name: Slanting
description: This error occurs when the issue is not treated fairly because of misrepresenting the evidence...
logicalForm: Presenting evidence in biased way
example: Reporting only negative statistics about an opponent's policy.

name: Slippery Slope
description: Suppose someone claims that a first step will probably lead to a second step that in turn will probably lead to another step and so on until a final step ends in trouble.
logicalForm: A leads to B, B leads to C,... Y leads to Z (disaster). Therefore, don't do A.
example: Legalizing marijuana will lead to harder drugs, then increased crime, then societal collapse.

name: Small Sample
description: This is the fallacy of using too small a sample.
logicalForm: Generalizing from small sample size N
example: My two experiences with that brand were bad, so all their products are bad.

name: Smear Tactic
description: A smear tactic is an unfair characterization either of the opponent or the opponent's position or argument.
logicalForm: Making false or misleading negative claims about opponent
example: Spreading rumors about opponent's personal life.

name: Smokescreen
description: This fallacy occurs by offering too many details in order either to obscure the point or to cover-up counter-evidence.
logicalForm: Overwhelming with irrelevant information to obscure main point
example: Responding to corruption allegations with lengthy discussions of policy achievements.

name: Sorites
description: See Line-Drawing.
logicalForm: Same as Line-Drawing
example: Same as Line-Drawing

name: Special Pleading
description: Special pleading is a form of inconsistency in which the reasoner doesn't apply his or her principles consistently.
logicalForm: Applying principle P generally but making exception for case C without justification
example: Free speech should be protected, except for views I disagree with.

name: Specificity
description: Drawing an overly specific conclusion from the evidence.
logicalForm: Evidence supports general conclusion G → Drawing overly specific conclusion S
example: Seeing wet streets and concluding it rained exactly 0.3 inches last night.

name: Stacking the Deck
description: See Suppressed Evidence and Slanting.
logicalForm: Same as Suppressed Evidence
example: Same as Suppressed Evidence

name: Stereotyping
description: Using stereotypes as if they are accurate generalizations for the whole group is an error in reasoning.
logicalForm: Group G has characteristic C. Therefore, member M of G has C.
example: Engineers are socially awkward. Therefore, this engineer must be socially awkward.

name: Straw Man
description: Your reasoning contains the Straw Man Fallacy whenever you attribute an easily refuted position to your opponent...
logicalForm: Misrepresenting opponent's position X as Y. Refuting Y. Claiming to have refuted X.
example: Opponent: We need police reform. You: They want to abolish all police! That would be disastrous!

name: Style Over Substance
description: Unfortunately the style with which an argument is presented is sometimes taken as adding to the substance or strength of the argument.
logicalForm: Argument A is presented in impressive style S. Therefore, A is strong.
example: The speaker was charismatic and eloquent, so their arguments must be valid.

name: Subjectivist
description: The Subjectivist Fallacy occurs when it is mistakenly supposed that a good reason to reject a claim is that truth on the matter is relative to the person or group.
logicalForm: Truth is subjective. Therefore, claim X is true for me but not for you.
example: That might be true for you, but not for me.

name: Superstitious Thinking
description: Reasoning deserves to be called superstitious if it is based on reasons that are well known to be unacceptable...
logicalForm: Belief based on magical thinking or false causation
example: Avoiding cracks in pavement to prevent 'bad luck'.

name: Suppressed Evidence
description: Intentionally failing to use information suspected of being relevant and significant...
logicalForm: Presenting evidence supporting position while suppressing contrary evidence
example: Promoting a drug's benefits while hiding side effects.

name: Sweeping Generalization
description: See Fallacy of Accident.
logicalForm: Same as Accident
example: Same as Accident

name: Syllogistic
description: Syllogistic fallacies are kinds of invalid categorical syllogisms.
logicalForm: Invalid categorical syllogism
example: All A are B. Some C are A. Therefore, all C are B. (Illicit major)

name: Tokenism
description: If you interpret a merely token gesture as an adequate substitute for the real thing...
logicalForm: Minor concession M made. Therefore, problem is solved.
example: We hired one woman, so we've addressed gender diversity.

name: Traditional Wisdom
description: If you say or imply that a practice must be OK today simply because it has been the apparently wise practice in the past...
logicalForm: X has been traditionally believed/done. Therefore, X is correct.
example: Marriage has always been between man and woman, so same-sex marriage is wrong.

name: Tu Quoque
description: The Fallacy of Tu Quoque occurs in our reasoning if we conclude that someone's argument not to perform some act must be faulty because the arguer himself or herself has performed it.
logicalForm: Person A criticizes action X. But A does X. Therefore, criticism is invalid.
example: You can't tell me to quit smoking when you smoke yourself!

name: Two Wrongs do not Make a Right
description: When you defend your wrong action as being right because someone previously has acted wrongly...
logicalForm: Wrong action W2 is justified because wrong action W1 occurred
example: They started it, so I can cheat too!

name: Undistributed Middle
description: In syllogistic logic, failing to distribute the middle term over at least one of the other terms...
logicalForm: All P are M. All S are M. Therefore, all S are P.
example: All dogs are mammals. All cats are mammals. Therefore, all cats are dogs.

name: Unfalsifiability
description: This error in explanation occurs when the explanation contains a claim that is not falsifiable...
logicalForm: Claim C cannot be tested/falsified
example: Invisible unicorns exist but only reveal themselves to believers.

name: Unrepresentative Generalization
description: If the plants on my plate are not representative of all plants, then the following generalization should not be trusted.
logicalForm: Generalizing from unrepresentative sample
example: Surveying only urban residents about gun control and generalizing to all citizens.

name: Unrepresentative Sample
description: If the means of collecting the sample from the population are likely to produce a sample that is unrepresentative of the population...
logicalForm: Sample S is unrepresentative of population P → Generalization from S to P unreliable
example: Concluding all Americans support war after surveying military bases.

name: Untestability
description: See Unfalsifiability.
logicalForm: Same as Unfalsifiability
example: Same as Unfalsifiability

name: Vested Interest
description: The Vested Interest Fallacy occurs when a person argues that someone's claim is incorrect or their recommended action is not worthy of being followed because the person is motivated by their interest in gaining something by it...
logicalForm: Person A has vested interest in claim X. Therefore, X is false.
example: She only supports that environmental policy because her company profits from it.

name: Victory by Definition
description: Same as the fallacy of Persuasive Definition.
logicalForm: Same as Persuasive Definition
example: Same as Persuasive Definition

name: Weak Analogy
description: See False Analogy.
logicalForm: Same as False Analogy
example: Same as False Analogy

name: Willed ignorance
description: I've got my mind made up, so don't confuse me with the facts.
logicalForm: Refusing to consider evidence against belief B
example: No evidence will change my mind about this!

name: Wishful Thinking
description: A reasoner who suggests that a claim is true, or false, merely because he or she strongly hopes it is...
logicalForm: I wish X were true. Therefore, X is true.
example: I really want there to be an afterlife, so there must be one.

name: You-Too
description: This is an informal name for the Tu Quoque fallacy.
logicalForm: Same as Tu Quoque
example: Same as Tu Quoque
